results.title: How language grows
results.creator_credit: John Honey, Barry Pierce and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the various stages of language development in children from birth to six-year-old. Shows how parents can positively support and contribute to their child’s language development.

results.title: How Jane Conquest Rang the Bell
results.brief_description: Jane’s conquest was a melodramatic magic lantern show which was hugely popular and performed with reading of poem by Dr Croft who rewrote and adapted the poem by James Milne. It featured an early form of special effects, by use of a second magic lantern slide projected over the first with a biunial magic lantern. This is considered to be an early form of superimpostion, which became a common effect in photography and cinematography. It consisted of 17 slides to be used on a biunial magic lantern, the 17th slide being of an angel to be superimposed over slide 4 and 16 to suggest the presence of an angel.

results.title: How it works
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
An explanation of how the furnace is constructed to withstand the very high temperatures needed to make steel. The system of regeneration by which gas and air are heated before being burned in the furnace is also illustrated.

results.title: How far how soon? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Eurfron Gwynne Jones and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
This program covers the range and pattern of normal physical development and, where possible, relates this to the emotional changes which occur. However, children of the same chronological age may vary enormously in their true maturity. This has implications for school assessment, relationships and the early choice of future careers.

results.title: How fair is the jury system?
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: An audience of students questions a prominent barrister on the fairness of the jury system. The program considers such issues as choosing a jury, eligibility of jurors and alternatives or reforms of the jury sustem.

results.title: How electricity is produced
results.creator_credit: Thomas Stanton, Pat Dowling and Pat Dowling Pictures
results.brief_description: Explains the three ways in which electricity is produced. Depicts Faraday discovering the principle of an induced current, and demonstrates with a small magneto-generator the principle of current electricity.

results.title: How do you drive?
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais, Walford Hewitson and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Released for general use as a public service by the Royal Canadian Air Force, this film demonstrates driving skills as taught at a National Defence Driving School. It follows the course of instruction of a new driver, and shows basic rules for handling a car under a variety of conditions, from turning a corner to halting a skid on ice.

results.title: How did she do it? A literary enquiry into the worldwide appeal of Agatha Christie
results.creator_credit: Toby Wallis, Stephen Hearst and Orsino Productions
results.brief_description: Structured as a mystery novel in itself, this documentary presented by Agatha Christie biographer, Janet Morgan, attempts to unravel the appeal and inspiration behind the Queen of crime. The program includes interviews with fellow crime writer P.D. James (who is not necessarily a big fan of the writer but can appreciate the “fairy tale” aspect to the work), editors, performers, critics and an international vox pop. The program looks at the tenets of Christie’s novels and provides solid biographical details to ascertain why she was compelled to write what she did so prolifically. Narrated by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: How cultures are studied
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In order to make credible studies of other cultures, the anthropologist must undertake field work. This program details the work of Napoleon A. Chagnon with the Yanamamo Indians of Venezuela, with whom he lived for extended periods of time. Professor Chagnon stresses the need for the anthropologist to participate in the culture he is studying and to abide by its rules. He describes the methods of data collection which he used in order to build up a comprehensive picture of this society as it was before it would inevitably become contaminated by the outside world. Narrated by David Carradine.
